So the functions is_latin_letter and is_punctuation need to be implemented as functions in Fortran. Implementing is_latin_letter:

logical function is_latin_letter(c)
   character, intent(in) :: c
   integer :: ich
   ich = ichar(c)
   is_latin_letter = (ich >= 97 .and. ich <= 122)
end function

Similarly, is_punctuation:

logical function is_punctuation(c)
   character, intent(in) :: c
   is_punctuation = (c == '.' .or. c == ',' .or. c == '?' .or. c == '!')
end function

Wait, the Java code's isPunctuation includes those four characters. So yes.

   character(len=1000) :: input_str, processed_str
   integer :: i, len_input
   character :: current_char, prev_char

   ! Read input

contains

   logical function is_latin_letter(c)
      character, intent(in) :: c
      integer :: ich
      ich = ichar(c)
      is_latin_letter = (ich >= 97 .and. ich <= 122)
   end function is_latin_letter

   logical function is_punctuation(c)
      character, intent(in) :: c
      is_punctuation = (c == '.' .or. c == ',' .or. c == '?' .or. c == '!')
   end function is_punctuation

end program main

   logical function is_punctuation(c)

      current_char = input_str(i:i)
      if (is_latin_letter(current_char)) then
         prev_char = input_str(i-1:i-1)
         if (.not. is_latin_letter(prev_char)) then
            processed_str = trim(processed_str) // ' '  ! Wait, but trim is not needed here. Because processed_str is built by appending, so it's not padded. So the current processed_str is exactly the characters added so far. So trim is unnecessary. So just:

            processed_str = processed_str // ' '
         end if
         processed_str = processed_str // current_char
      else if (is_punctuation(current_char)) then
         processed_str = processed_str // current_char
      end if
   end do

   ! Now process the second step.

   if (len_trim(processed_str) == 0) then
      write(*,*) ''
   else
      character :: first_char
      first_char = processed_str(1:1)
      integer :: c_val
      c_val = ichar(first_char) + 1
      character :: new_char
      new_char = char(c_val)
      write(*,'(A)') new_char
   end if

contains

   logical function is_latin_letter(c)
      character, intent(in) :: c
      integer :: ich
      ich = ichar(c)
      is_latin_letter = (ich >= 97 .and. ich <= 122)
   end function is_latin_letter

   logical function is_punctuation(c)
      character, intent(in) :: c
      is_punctuation = (c == '.' .or. c == ',' .or. c == '?' .or. c == '!')
   end function is_punctuation

end program main

Wait, but in the first step, when building processed_str, the initial assignment is input_str(1:1). But if the input_str is longer than 1 character, then the loop starts at i=2. So that's okay.

Another possible issue: when the input_str has length 1. Then the loop doesn't run, and processed_str is just the first character. Then the second step takes that character, adds 1, and outputs.

Another test case: input "A" → first character 'A' (not a letter), so processed_str is "A". The second step adds 1 → 'B'.

character(len=20000) :: processed_str

Another thing: in Fortran, when you do 'processed_str = processed_str // ' ', the right-hand side must not exceed the left-hand side's length. So with the lengths set as above, it should be okay.
